lesson.name: Lesson 7.3: Building Quadratic Functions from Geometric Patterns

page.title: 7.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to work with patterns but begin to see these relationships as quadratic functions and write equations to define them.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Recognize quadratic functions written in different ways.
  • Use information from a pattern of shapes to write a quadratic function.
  • Know that, in a pattern of shapes, the step number is the input and the number of squares is the output.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.3.1: Quadratic Expressions and Area
  • 7.3.2: Writing Equations for Patterns with Squares
    • 7.3.2: Self Check
    • 7.3.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.3.3: Quadratic Sequences
    • 7.3.3: Self Check
    • 7.3.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.3.4: Quadratic Function?

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.3.5: Practice
  • 7.3.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.3.1: Quadratic Expressions and Area
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Figure A is a large square. Figure B is a large square with a smaller square removed. Figure C is composed of two large squares with one smaller square added.

Figure A

Figure B

Figure C

Write an expression to represent the area of each shaded figure when the side length of the large square is as shown in the first column.

Copy and complete the table. Compare your work by answering questions 1-12.

Side length of
large square

Area of A

Area of B

Area of C

\(4\)

\(x\)

\(4x\)

\(x+3\)


  1. When the side length of the large square is \(4\), what is the area of figure A?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(4^2\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(4\), what is the area of figure B?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(4^2-1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(4\), what is the area of figure C?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(2(4^2)+1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(x\), what is the area of figure A?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(x\), what is the area of figure B?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2-1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(x\), what is the area of figure C?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(2x^2+1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(4x\), what is the area of figure A?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(16x^2\) or \((4x)^2\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(4x\), what is the area of figure B?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(16x^2-1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(4x\), what is the area of figure C?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(32x^2+1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(x+3\), what is the area of figure A?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x+3)^2\) or \((x+3)(x+3)\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(x+3\), what is the area of figure B?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x+3)^2-1\) (or an equivalent expression)



  1. When the side length of the large square is \(x+3\), what is the area of figure C

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(2(x+3)^2+1\) (or an equivalent expression)

page.title: 7.3.2: Writing Equations for Patterns with Squares
page.contents:
Activity


  1. If the pattern continues, what will we see in Step 5 and Step 18?
    1. Sketch or describe the figure in each of these steps.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Step 5 is a collection of 25 small squares, in a 5-by-5 arrangement, surrounded by 4 other small squares at the corners. Step 18 is a collection of \(18^2\) small squares, in an 18 by 18 arrangement, surrounded by 4 other small squares at the corners.



    1. How many small squares are in each of these steps? Explain how you know.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Step 5: 29, because it is \(5^2+4\) or \((5 \cdot 5)+4\). Step 18: 328, because it is \(18^2+4\) or \((18 \cdot 18)+4\).



  1. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\). Be prepared to explain how each part of your equation relates to the pattern. (If you get stuck, try making a table.)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=n^2+4\) or equivalent. The \(n^2\) term represents the number of small squares in the central \(n\)-by-\(n\) large square. The 4 represents the 4 small squares that are added to the large square at its 4 corners.



  1. Sketch the first three steps of a pattern that can be represented by the equation \(y=n^2-1\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

An \(n\)-by-\(n\) array of squares with one square missing at the top right. The first step (for \(n=1\)) will have no squares.



Extending Your Thinking

  1. For the original step pattern in the statement, \(y=n^2+4\), write an equation to represent the relationship between the step number, \(n\), and the perimeter, \(P\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(P=4n+16\)



  1. For the step pattern you created in Part 3 of the activity, \(y=n^2-1\), write an equation to represent the relationship between the step number, \(n\), and the perimeter, \(P\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

If the pattern was an \(n\)-by-\(n\) array of squares with a square missing from the corner, the perimeter could be given by \(P=0\) when \(n=1\), and by \(P=4n\) when \(n>1\).



  1. Are these linear functions?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes, in both cases, these are linear functions.

page.title: 7.3.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation represents the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This only works for the first step. The answer is \(y=n^2+1\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This only works for the second step. The answer is \(y=n^2+1\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: When \(n\) is the number of steps, there are \(n\) rows and \(n\) columns, or \(n\) times \(n\), then one additional block.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The base of the area is always \(n\), but the height is not always \(n+1\). The answer is \(y=n^2+1\).

page.title: 7.3.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Patterns Represented by Quadratics

See Steps 1–3 of a pattern of squares below. Write an equation representing the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\).

Make a table for the number of columns and rows of each step and the number of squares:

Step

# of columns

# of rows

# of squares

1

1

3

3

2

2

6

12

3

3

9

27

\(n\)

\(n\)

\(3n\)

\(3n^2\)

First, count how many columns there are in each step (the length):

For each, there are \(n\) columns.

Next, count how many rows there are in each step (the height): 

For each, there are \(3n\) rows.

The area of this figure is then \(l \times h\) or \(n \times 3n\), which becomes \(y=3n^2\).

Try It: Patterns Represented by Quadratics

See Steps 1–3 of a pattern of squares below. Write an equation representing the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\).


Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to represent this pattern as a quadratic:

Make a table for the number of columns and rows of each step and the number of squares:

Step

# of columns

# of rows

# of squares

1

0

0

0

2

2

2

3

3

3

3

8

\(n\)

\(n\)

\(n\)

\(n^2-1\)

For this pattern, notice that the area would be the number of columns times the number of rows, but then one block is subtracted.

Note that for Step 1, there was a \(1 \times 1\) block there, but then it was subtracted with the equation given.

The equation, then, is \(y=n^2-1\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.3.3: Quadratic Sequences
page.contents:
Activity


  1. Sketch the next step in the pattern. Explain what you sketched.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Step 4 is a 4-by-6 rectangle.



  1. Kiran says that the pattern is growing linearly because as the step number goes up by 1, the number of rows and the number of columns also increase by 1. Do you agree? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Kiran is correct that the number of rows and the number of columns each grow by 1, but the total number of squares does not increase by the same amount from step to step. So, the total number of squares does not grow linearly.



  1. To represent the number of squares after \(n\) steps, Diego and Jada wrote different equations. Diego wrote the equation \(f(n)=n(n+2)\). Jada wrote the equation \(f(n)=n^2+2n\). Is either Diego or Jada correct? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Diego’s expression \(n(n+2)\) is correct because there are \(n\) columns and \(n+2\) rows of small squares in Step \(n\). Jada’s expression is also correct because the \(n(n+2)\) array of small squares can be divided into an \(n\)-by-\(n\) square (having \(n^2\) small squares) and an \(n\)-by-2 rectangle (having \(2n\) small squares).


Video: Quadratic Sequences

Watch the following video to learn more about quadratic sequences.

page.title: 7.3.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation represents the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the number of rows only. The answer is \(y=n^2+n\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: There are \(n+1\) rows and \(n\) columns. The number of blocks in each step would be \(n(n+1)\), which equals \(n^2+n\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of rows is \(n+1\), and the number of columns is \(n\). Be sure to distribute the \(n\) to both terms when multiplying. The answer is \(y=n^2+n\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This only works for Step 1. The answer is \(y=n^2+n\).

page.title: 7.3.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
More Complex Quadratic Patterns

See Steps 1–3 of a pattern of squares below. Write an equation representing the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\).

First, try to find the pattern if the missing squares were actually there.

Make a table:

Step

# of columns

# of rows

# of squares

1

2

2

2

2

2

2

7

3

4

4

14

\(n\)

\(n + 1\)

\(n + 1\)

\((n+1)^2-2\)

There would be \((n+1)(n+1)\) squares, but there are 2 missing from each step, so the equation would be:

\(y=(n+1)^2-2\).

Try It: More Complex Quadratic Patterns

See Steps 1–3 of a pattern of squares below. Write an equation representing the relationship between the step number \(n\) and the number of squares \(y\).


Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to represent the quadratic sequence with an equation:

Notice there are no missing squares. Complete the table for each step:

Step

# of columns

# of rows

# of squares

1

4

4

16

2

5

5

25

3

6

6

36

\(n\)

\(n + 3\)

\(n + 3\)

\((n+3)^2\)

The number of columns is always \(n+3\), and the number of rows is \(n+3\).

The number of squares will be represented by \(y=(n+3)^2\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.3.4: Quadratic Function?
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity


  1. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the step number and the number of squares in the pattern. Briefly describe how each part of the equation relates to the pattern.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=n^2+n\) or equivalent because there is an \(n\)-by-\(n\) array of small squares, which gives \(n^2\), and then there is a row of \(n\) squares in the lower right.



  1. Is the relationship between the step number and the number of squares a quadratic function? Explain how you know.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The relationship is a quadratic function because the number of squares could be expressed as \(n^2+n\), which is a quadratic expression.

page.title: 7.3.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Sketch or describe the figure in Step 4 and Step 15.

    1. How many small squares are in Step 4?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Step 4 is a 4-by-4 array of squares with the lower-left corner square moved to the upper-right corner.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.2 and 7.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 16. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many small squares are in Step 15?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct! Step 15 is a 15-by-15 array of squares with the lower-left corner square moved to the upper-right corner.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.2 and 7.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 225. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which equation represents the relationship between the step number, \(n\), and the number of small squares, \(y\), in each step?

Correct! \(y=n^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.2 and 7.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=n^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Each figure is composed of large squares and small squares. The side length of the large square is \(x\). Choose the correct expression that represents the area, \(y\), of the shaded part of each figure.
    1. Figure A

Correct! \(y=x^2-4\) The figure is an \(x\)-by-\(x\) square with 4 unit squares that aren’t shaded.

Try Again! Why don't you go back to activity 7.3.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=x^2-4\). The figure is an \(x\)-by-\(x\) square with 4 unit squares that aren’t shaded. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Figure B

Correct! \(y=2x^2+8\). There are two squares that are \(x\) by \(x\), and there are smaller squares that are 4 units each added to the figure.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.3.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=2x^2+8\). There are two squares that are \(x\) by \(x\), and there are smaller squares that are 4 units each added to the figure. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use the sequence below to answer questions a and b.

    1. How many squares are in Step 5?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct! Every step has one more row and column than the step number, and then one square is taken away.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.3 and 7.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 35. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Choose the correct expression that represents the area, \(y\), of the shaded part of each figure for \(n\) steps.

Correct! \((n+1)^2-1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.3.3 and 7.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((n+1)^2-1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.3.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Recognize quadratic functions written in different ways.
  • Use information from a pattern of shapes to write a quadratic function.
  • Know that, in a pattern of shapes, the step number is the input and the number of squares is the output.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.3.1: Quadratic Expressions and Area
    • In this activity, you represented the areas of shaded figures formed from squares with quadratic expressions.
  • 7.3.2: Writing Equations for Patterns with Squares
    • In this activity, you looked at visual patterns to write quadratic functions that represent sequences.
    • 7.3.2: Self Check
    • 7.3.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.3.3: Quadratic Sequences
    • In this activity, you explored more quadratic functions from visual sequences that involved quadratic expressions written in different forms.
    • 7.3.3: Self Check
    • 7.3.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.3.4: Quadratic Function?
    • In this activity, you wrote a quadratic function from a pattern that did not have a constant.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.3.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
